references: Table II presents accuracy comparisons on three datasets under both NIID-1 and NIID-2 settings. For each entry in the table, we run three independent trials and report the mean and standard deviation results. We see that i) FedFM consistently outperforms other state-of-the-art methods on all tasks. ii) On the relatively more complicated task, NIID-1 setting on CIFAR100, the proposed FedFM significantly outperforms other methods. Specifically, compared with standard FL, FedAvgÂ [1], FedFM achieves 9.40%percent9.409.40\% higher accuracy. iii) On the six different tasks, FedFM outperforms the second-best method (SCAFFOLDÂ [7]) 2.98%,3.04%,3.96%,4.97%,4.16%,4.89%percent2.98percent3.04percent3.96percent4.97percent4.16percent4.892.98\%,3.04\%,3.96\%,4.97\%,4.16\%,4.89\%, respectively. It is also worth mentioning that SCAFFOLDÂ [7] requires roughly twice the memory and communication bandwidth costs.

references: Table III shows the accuracy, memory, bandwidth comparisons under NIID-3 setting on CIFAR-10. In NIID-3, each client has no data sample from several (xğ‘¥x) categories, which is denoted as Missing xğ‘¥x setting. We conduct experiments on different xâˆˆ{1,2,3,5,7}ğ‘¥12357x\in\{1,2,3,5,7\}. We see that i) the performances of all methods degrade as xğ‘¥x increases since larger xğ‘¥x corresponds to a more heterogeneous setting. This verifies that data heterogeneity significantly affects the performance of FL. ii) FedFM consistently outperforms other state-of-the-art methods. Specifically, it outperforms FedAvgÂ [1] by 5.53%percent5.535.53\% and SCAFFOLDÂ [7] by 2.28%percent2.282.28\% on average. iii) Compared with FedAvgÂ [1], FedFM achieves significantly better performance while introducing minor memory and bandwidth costs. Compared with SCAFFOLDÂ [7], FedFM achieves better performance with nearly half of the memory and bandwidth costs.

S7.T4.caption: TABLE IV: Numerical quality evaluation of feature spaces. Higher NMI and SS correspond to higher quality of feature spaces. Our proposed FedFM achieves significantly highest NMI and SS.
S7.T4.table:
Metric FedAvgÂ [1] FedAvgMÂ [19] FedProxÂ [6] SCAFFOLDÂ [7] FedDynÂ [16] FedNovaÂ [18] MOONÂ [20] FedFM (ours)
NMI 0.413 0.411 0.397 0.432 0.485 0.416 0.481 0.557
SS 0.036 0.038 0.006 0.056 0.136 0.049 0.068 0.173
references: For more comprehensive comparisons, we also evaluate the quality of feature space in Fig.Â 6 using normalized mutual information (NMI) and silhouette score (SS)Â [42]. NMI is capable of measuring the quality of clustering. SS is a measure of how similar an object is to its own cluster compared to other clusters. Note that for NMI, we first apply the K-MeansÂ [43] to perform clustering on sampled features of all methods and then use NMI to measure the clustering quality. Both NMI and SS are mesured using Scikit-learnÂ [44]. Higher NMI and SS correspond to higher quality of feature spaces. We present the evaluation results in TableÂ IV. The table shows that our proposed FedFM achieves significantly higher NMI and SS. Specifically, compared with FedDynÂ [16], FedFM achieves 14.8%percent14.814.8\% higher NMI and 27.2%percent27.227.2\% higher SS. This gives evidence for the seemly great feature space but ordinary accuracy performance of FedDynÂ [16] in a way.

references: FedFM introduces minor resource costs while bringing significantly better performance. To verify this point, we conduct experiments on CIFAR-100Â [21] under various client numbers (Kâˆˆ{20,30,50,100}ğ¾203050100K\in\{20,30,50,100\}). Beside accuracy comparisons, we also compare the memory and bandwidth cost of these methods, which are evaluated by the number of required floating numbers (Ã—108absentsuperscript108\times 10^{8}) for the overall FL process. We present the results in TableÂ V. Experiments show that i) our proposed FedFM consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods for various client numbers, indicating its applicability to scenario with large client number. ii) FedFM achieves significantly better performance with minor additional memory and bandwidth overhead. Specifically, FedFM takes only 0.86%percent0.860.86\% more communication overhead to achieve 13.97%percent13.9713.97\% better classification performance than FedAvgÂ [1] when K=100ğ¾100K=100. Compared with the second-best method (SCAFFOLDÂ [7]), FedFM achieves 7.68%percent7.687.68\% higher accuracy when K=100ğ¾100K=100 with only half the memory and bandwidth costs.

S7.T6.caption: TABLE VI: Effects of global anchors aggregation manner. (Weighted) denotes aggregating category-wise anchors according to each clientâ€™s number of corresponding samples. (Uniform) denotes computing simple arithmetic mean of anchors. Experiments show that FedFM (Uniform) performs comparably with FedFM (Weighted) while FedFM (Uniform) does not need uploading clientâ€™s category distribution.
S7.T6.table:
Method FedAvgÂ [1] FedFM (Weighted) FedFM (Uniform)
Accuracy 66.69 Â±0.69plus-or-minus0.69\pm 0.69 72.89 Â±0.22plus-or-minus0.22\pm 0.22 72.87 Â±0.26plus-or-minus0.26\pm 0.26
references: We conduct experiments under NIID-1 on CIFAR-10Â [21] and present the results in TableÂ VI. Experiments show that FedFM with uniform aggregation performs comparably to FedFM with weighted aggregation (only 0.02%percent0.020.02\% performance drop). The reason behind this could be that for each category, all clientsâ€™ features are pushed to the same shared global anchor. As a result, all clientsâ€™ local anchors of the same category are close to each other, making it similar between applying weighted aggregation and uniform aggregation.
